prj:ScienceGoal.prj:name: Science Goal
prj:ScienceGoal.prj:note: We will make a 2-D map of the first velocity moment of the CO emission in Band 3 for NGC 4150 and 4310 in order to make a rotation curve for the galaxy. The NGC 4150 has a diameter of about 2 arcminutes and will be mosaiced. The sources are within 10 arcmin of one another.

prj:TechnicalJustification.prj:justificationText:
The observations require a spatial resolution of 2 arcsec which provides a linear resolution of about 150 pc at the typical target distance of 15 Mpc. This is the resolution necessary to resolve a core the size of 300 pc. A 2 arcsec beam also matches the resolution of the Palomar IFU allowing for a good complematarity between observations made with the two instruments. A velocity resolution of 2 km/s is needed to provide the velocity precision in the inner parts of the galaxies where the rotational velocities are less than 10 km/s. We desire a sensitivity to be able to detect at least one Milky Way-type GMC in each synthesized beams at a level of two sigma, though the peak of the emission is expected to be many sigma.
A Milky Way GMC has a typical diameter of about 50 pc. A GMC therefore subtends about 12% of a synthesized beam area at 15 Mpc. A typical GMC has a mean brightness temperature of about 4 K, so a single GMC will have an observed brightness temperature of 0.12 x 4K = 480 mK. With a 2 arcsec beam, the ALMA control and performance tab gives a sensitivity of ~600 mK. For a frequency resolution of 2 km/s, this takes 52 minutes of integration with 20 min on source. For a typical GMC linewidth of 8 km/s this gives about a one sigma detection in one 2km/s wide plane in the data cube for a single GMC. Since a detection will have 4 adjacent channels, with a 20 minute on-source observation will be able to detect a GMC at the requested sensitivity.

prj:ScienceGoal.prj:name: Science Goal
prj:ScienceGoal.prj:note: Will make observations of NGC 4701, NGC 4376 and NGC 4451 which are within 10 deg of each other on the sky to make rotation curves of these galaxies. Will mosaic as necessary.

prj:ScienceGoal.prj:note: We will make band 3 observations of the 2D velociy field of NGC 1035 and will make a 7 point mosaic inorder to measure the rotation curve of the galaxy

prp:ObsProposal.prp:abstract: The dwarf galaxy dark matter survey described in this proposal will measure the radial distribution of dark matter (DM) in a sample of 13 DM dominated dwarf galaxies. The goal of the project is to determine the functional form of the DM distribution on scales of a hundred parsecs, and the degree to which the DM varies from galaxy to galaxy as a text of the Lambda CDM model on small scales. The scope of the project will permit for the first time the possibility of correlating the DM properites with other galaxy properties such as mass, gas density, star formation history, etc. We will measure the DM distribution by combining 2-D velocity fields of the galaxies in CO, which provides the least biased and coldest kinematic tracer at small radii together with Palomar Halpha integral field spectroscopy to extend the measurements to larger radii. Together with near-infrared imaging to secure the stellar mass distribution, we will remove the baryonic contribution to the observed rotation and model the kinematics. This data set will be the largest homogenious survey of the DM in the inner regions of galaxies undertaken to date.
